title: SemanticDistance
code: #install.packages("devtools") #to install devlopment version, run this #devtools::install_github("Reilly-ConceptsCognitionLab/ConversationAlign") #installs from github library(SemanticDistance) #> Warning: replacing previous import 'magrittr::extract' by 'tidyr::extract' when #> loading 'SemanticDistance' #> Warning: replacing previous import 'magrittr::set_names' by 'rlang::set_names' #> when loading 'SemanticDistance'

title: SemanticDistance
text: SemanticDistance cleans formats target text applying variety options (e.g., leave alone, clean punctuation, omit stopwords, lemmatize strings). package can handle variety dataframe formats, including ordered monologues, word pairs arrayed columns, unordered word lists, dialogue transcripts marked talker information. SemanticDistance scans cleaned/formatted dataframe computes two different metrics semantic distance successive chunks (e.g., ngrams, words, turns). two semantic distance values reflect pairwise cosine distance (0 2) two different high dimensional semantic spaces. Experiential semantic distance (SD15) reflects pairwise distance two word vectors (e.g., dog:cat) spanning 15 meaningful semantic dimensions (e.g., color, sound, valence). Embedding-based semantic distances (Glo) derived contrasting word’s semantic vector spanning 300 hyperparameters trained GLOVE word embedding model.

what: Step 1: Clean and Prep Your Text
title: SemanticDistance
text: SemanticDistance works monologues (talker information), dialogues (two speakers), word pairs arrayed columns, unstructured word lists (hierarchical clustering). Cleaning can even handle unstructured text pasted single cell csv file. However, MUST run appropriate cleaning function run distance functions even apply cleaning options. functions append unique identifiers used distance calculations. Prep string data (csv text) read R (e.g., myrawdat). Call objects variables anything like. SemanticDistance retain metadata. data contain least one column string data (e.g., mytext). Identify format sample (e.g., monologue, dialogue, columns, unstructured). Decide cleaning parameters (lemmatize, omit stopwords, omit punctuation). Specify cleaning function arguments best fit aims.

previous_headings: Step 1: Clean and Prep Your Text
title: SemanticDistance
text: story etc. - basically string word order matters don’t care talker information. target text split unlisted one word per row format.metadata retained. ’s sample monologue sorts junk column called ‘word’. ‘clean_monologue’ function split append unique identifier word retaining empty strings meaningful. Defaults omit stopwords lemmatize.

what: Step 2: Compute Semantic Distance on your Prepped Data
title: SemanticDistance
text: SemanticDistance append cosine distance values pair elements specified user (e.g., word--word, ngram--word). distance values derived two large lookup databases package fixed semantic vectors >70k English words. CosDist_Glo reflects cosine distance vectors derived training GLOVE word embedding model (300 hyperparameters per word). CodDist_SD15 refects cosine distance two chunks (words, groups words) characterized across 15 meaningful perceptual affective dimensions (e.g., color, sound, valence). Users specify ngram window size. window rolls successively language sample compute semantic distance value new word relative n-words (ngram size) . model compouting distance illustrated figure. larger specified ngram size smoothed semantic vector language sample. settle window size clean language transcript (works monologues ), ready roll. ’s general idea…

previous_headings: Step 2: Compute Semantic Distance on your Prepped Data
title: SemanticDistance
text: Joins target transcript lookup database word corresponding semantic vector row form. example, interested 4-word chunks, dog-cat-milk-banana (Ngram_4) first ngram. aggregate semantic vectors four words mean vector 4-gram compute distance next 4-gram iterating dataframe last possible chunk four words omitting ‘leftovers’ (residual/remainder divisible ngram size). example 22 words user interested 3-grams, 7 one word left last row.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Jamie Reilly. Author, maintainer. Hannah Mechtenberg. Author. Emily Myers. Author. Jonathan Peelle. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Reilly J, Mechtenberg H, Myers E, Peelle J (2025). SemanticDistance: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Successive Units Language Samples. R package version 0.1.0, https://github.com/Reilly-ConceptsCognitionLab/SemanticDistance.
code: @Manual{,   title = {SemanticDistance: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples},   author = {Jamie Reilly and Hannah Mechtenberg and Emily Myers and Jonathan Peelle},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://github.com/Reilly-ConceptsCognitionLab/SemanticDistance}, }

title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
text: SemanticDistance nominally requires dataframe least one column variable one row text. package capable processing many dataframe formats (e.g., word pairs arrayed columns, conversation transcripts, unordered word lists). SemanticDistance retain original metadata splitting/unlisting text one-word-per-row structure. sequential structure ideal joining distance values timestamps variables language unfolds (e.g., reaction time, pupil diameter).

title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
text: Install development version SemanticDistance GitHub using devtools.
code: #install.packages("devtools") #devtools::install_github("Reilly-ConceptsCognitionLab/SemanticDistance") library(SemanticDistance)

title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
text: Sometimes care computing time-ordered semantic distances words running discourse sampples. times word order doesn’t matter (e.g., using simple machine learning algorithm cluster bag words similarity). Sometimes data structured monologues (e.g., stories, narratives). times might interested computing semantic distance turn--turn across speakers conversation transcript (.e., dialogue). SemanticDistance pockage can handle scenarios. However, important understand structure data distance measures mean. formats SemanticDistance can currently handle:  1. Monologues: monologue transcript consists ordered text sample delineated talker/speaker (e.g., stories, narratives). minimal requirement monologue one row one column text . 2. Dialogues: dialogue transcript includes sample split talker/speaker/interlocutor information including conversation transcripts. minimum requirment two cells interlocutor identity text. 3. Word Pairs Columns: dataframe contains two columns paired string data (col1 vs. col2). Calculates distance word pair across columns (e.g., Dog-Leash).  4. Unordered Word Lists: dataframe unordered list words (nominally one column, text one row) transformed distance matrix hierarchically clustered

what: Sample language transcripts embedded in the package
title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
text: SemanticDistance contains sample language transcripts automatically load call package. can helpful evaluating debugging data. Monologue_Structured: Dataframe 1-word per row already split missing observations Monologue_Dirty: Dataframe text arrayed one column ‘mytext’, missing observations, junk, multiword phrases contains metadata (simulated timestamps Monologue_VerbalFluency: Dataframe ordered simulated semantic fluency data switching categories every ten words (animals, tools, musical instruments, fruits) Dialogue_Structured: Dataframe simulating ‘perfect’ conversation transcript, one word per turn, two talkers Dialogue_Dirty: #Dataframe simulating ‘dirty’ conversation transcript, multiple lines per person, lots stopwords, missing obervations, stray transcription symbols WordPairs_Columns: #Dataframe word pairs arrayed two columns WordList_TestClustering: Unordered unsplit word list, junk also animal weapon terms hierachical clustering analysis

what: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
text: First identify type data structure want process (e.g., monologue, dialogue, unordered list). semantic distance functions work indexing unique numeric identifiers. MUST first clean/prep raw text append identifers. Prepare lexical data computing pairwise semantic distances first following: Read data R. Label text metadata columns however like. dataframe contain least one column target string data (e.g., mytext). Identify format sample (e.g., monologue, dialogue, columns, unstructured). Decide cleaning parameters (lemmatize, omit stopwords, omit punctuation). Run approproate cleaning function specifying parameters best fit data aims.

title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
text: Clean monologue transcript calling ‘clean_monologue’ function. Specific arguments include: df = raw dataframe least one column text wordcol = quoted variable reflecting column name target text lives (e.g., ‘mytext’) clean = applies cleaning functions (e.g., punct , lowercase, etc); default TRUE omit_stops = omits stopwords, default TRUE lemmatize = transforms raw word lemmatized form, default TRUE

what: Output of ‘clean_monologue’ on cleaning a dirty monologue transcript
title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
code: #text in this dataframe is in a column 'mytext' MyCleanMonologue1 <- clean_monologue(Monologue_Dirty, 'mytext', clean=T) head(MyCleanMonologue1, n=10) #> # A tibble: 10 × 3 #>    mytext            id_orig word_clean #>    <chr>             <fct>   <chr>      #>  1 The dog is blue.  1       ""         #>  2 The dog is blue.  1       "dog"      #>  3 The dog is blue.  1       "blue"     #>  4 Dog               2       "dog"      #>  5 Dog               3       "dog"      #>  6 Some              4       ""         #>  7 My name is Frank. 5       ""         #>  8 My name is Frank. 5       "name"     #>  9 My name is Frank. 5       "frank"    #> 10 Dog               6       "dog"

what: Output of ‘clean_monologue’ on a structured monologue transcript
title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
code: #text in this dataframe is in a column 'mytext' MyCleanMonologue2 <- clean_monologue(Monologue_Structured, 'mytext', clean=T) head(MyCleanMonologue2, n=10) #> # A tibble: 10 × 4 #>    timestamp mytext    id_orig word_clean #>        <int> <chr>     <fct>   <chr>      #>  1         1 "the"     1       ""         #>  2         2 "girl"    2       "girl"     #>  3         3 "walked"  3       "walk"     #>  4         4 "down "   4       "down"     #>  5         5 "the "    5       ""         #>  6         6 "street"  6       "street"   #>  7         7 "the"     7       ""         #>  8         8 "boxer"   8       "boxer"    #>  9         9 "punched" 9       "punch"    #> 10        10 "the"     10      ""

title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
text: conversation transcript language sample care talker/interlocutor information (e.g., computing semantic distance across turns conversation). dataframe nominally contain text column speaker/talker column. Arguments clean_dialogue :  | df = raw dataframe least one column text talker column | wordcol = column name (quoted) containing text want cleaned | whotalks = column name (quoted) containing talker ID (convert factor) | clean = T/F (default T) applies cleaning functions | omit_stops = T/F omits stopwords, default TRUE | lemmatize = T/F transforms raw word lemmatized form, default TRUE

what: Output of ‘clean_dialogue’ prepping a well-structured dialogue transcript
title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
code: My_CleanDialogue1 <- clean_dialogue(Dialogue_Structured, "mytext", "speaker", omit_stops=T, lemmatize=T) head(My_CleanDialogue1, n=8) #> # A tibble: 8 × 6 #>   mytext    speaker id_orig talker word_clean turn_count #>   <chr>     <chr>   <fct>   <fct>  <chr>           <dbl> #> 1 donkey    P1      1       P1     donkey              1 #> 2 astronaut P2      2       P2     astronaut           2 #> 3 bubble    P1      3       P1     bubble              3 #> 4 street    P2      4       P2     street              4 #> 5 Pigeon    P1      5       P1     pigeon              5 #> 6 Dolphin   P2      6       P2     dolphin             6 #> 7 Eagle     P1      7       P1     eagle               7 #> 8 eel       P2      8       P2     eel                 8

what: 1.3 Clean Word Pairs Arrayed in Columns (clean_2columns)
title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
text: SemanticDistance also computes pairwise distance data arrayed columns. Run function, cleaned columns appear dataframe. Arguments ‘clean_monologue’ function call :  | df = raw dataframe least one column text | word1 = quoted variable reflecting column name first word lives | word2 = quoted variable reflecting column name first word lives | clean = T/F (default T) applies cleaning functions | omit_stops = T/F omits stopwords, default TRUE | lemmatize = T/F transforms raw word lemmatized form, default TRUE

previous_headings: 1.3 Clean Word Pairs Arrayed in Columns (clean_2columns)
what: Output of ‘clean_2columns’ cleaning word pairs arrayed in columns
title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
code: MyClean2Columns <- clean_2cols(WordPairs_Columns, 'word1', 'word2', clean=T, omit_stops=T, lemmatize=T) head(MyClean2Columns, n=8) #view head cleaned data #>   word1     word2 id_orig word1_clean1 word2_clean2 #> 1   Dog   trumpet       1          dog      trumpet #> 2   the    BANANA       2          the       banana #> 3   rat astronaut       3          rat    astronaut #> 4  *&^%    lizard       4         <NA>       lizard #> 5  bird      bird       5         bird         bird #> 6 shark     shark       6        shark        shark #> 7 table     38947       7        table         <NA> #> 8   Dog     leash       8          dog        leash

title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
text: cleaning option used prepping vector words hierarchical clustering. Word order longer factor since words shuffled. cleaning function retains one instance word (duplicates). Arguments ‘clean_unordered4matrix’ function call :  | df = raw dataframe least one column text | wordcol = quoted variable reflecting text lives | clean = T/F (default T) applies cleaning functions | omit_stops = T/F omits stopwords, default TRUE | lemmatize = T/F transforms raw word lemmatized form, default TRUE

what: Output of ‘clean_unordered4matrix’ on unordered word list
title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
code: #Run clean fn  MyCleanDat4Matrix <- clean_unordered4matrix(WordList_TestClustering, wordcol="mytext", clean=TRUE, omit_stops=TRUE, lemmatize=TRUE)  head(MyCleanDat4Matrix, n=8) #> # A tibble: 8 × 3 #>   mytext                                                      id_orig word_clean #>   <chr>                                                         <int> <chr>      #> 1 dog cat $ Rat gun banana the sword table glasses phone sof…       1 dog        #> 2 dog cat $ Rat gun banana the sword table glasses phone sof…       1 cat        #> 3 dog cat $ Rat gun banana the sword table glasses phone sof…       1 rat        #> 4 dog cat $ Rat gun banana the sword table glasses phone sof…       1 gun        #> 5 dog cat $ Rat gun banana the sword table glasses phone sof…       1 banana     #> 6 dog cat $ Rat gun banana the sword table glasses phone sof…       1 sword      #> 7 dog cat $ Rat gun banana the sword table glasses phone sof…       1 table      #> 8 dog cat $ Rat gun banana the sword table glasses phone sof…       1 glass

title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
text: SemanticDistance append cosine distance values pair elements specified user (e.g., word--word, ngram--word). distance values derived two large lookup databases package fixed semantic vectors >70k English words. CosDist_Glo reflects cosine distance vectors derived training GLOVE word embedding model (300 hyperparameters per word). CodDist_SD15 refects cosine distance two chunks (words, groups words) characterized across 15 meaningful perceptual affective dimensions (e.g., color, sound, valence). Users specify ngram window size. window rolls successively language sample compute semantic distance value new word relative n-words (ngram size) . model compouting distance illustrated figure. larger specified ngram size smoothed semantic vector language sample. settle window size clean language transcript (works monologues ), ready roll. ’s general idea…

title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
text: Computes cosine distance two models (embedding experiential) using rolling ngram approach consisting groups words (ngrams) next word.  Remember call cleaned/prepped dataframe! Arguments ‘dist_ngram2word’ :  | dat dataframe monologue transcript cleaned prepped clean_monologue fn  | ngram ngram window size preceding new content word

title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
text: Set ngram=1, distance every word next
code: MyNgram2WordDists1 <- dist_ngram2word(MyCleanMonologue1, ngram=1) #distance word-to-word head(MyNgram2WordDists1, n=8) #> # A tibble: 8 × 5 #>   mytext            id_orig word_clean CosDist_1gram_glo CosDist_1gram_sd15 #>   <chr>             <fct>   <chr>                  <dbl>              <dbl> #> 1 The dog is blue.  1       ""                    NA                  NA    #> 2 The dog is blue.  1       "dog"                 NA                  NA    #> 3 The dog is blue.  1       "blue"                 0.607               1.44 #> 4 Dog               2       "dog"                  0.607               1.44 #> 5 Dog               3       "dog"                  0                   0    #> 6 Some              4       ""                    NA                  NA    #> 7 My name is Frank. 5       ""                    NA                  NA    #> 8 My name is Frank. 5       "name"                NA                  NA

title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
text: Set ngram=3, distance rolling chunks 3 words next word
code: MyNgram2WordDists2 <- dist_ngram2word(MyCleanMonologue2, ngram=3) #distance word-to-word head(MyNgram2WordDists2, n=12) #> # A tibble: 12 × 6 #>    timestamp mytext     id_orig word_clean CosDist_3gram_glo CosDist_3gram_sd15 #>        <int> <chr>      <fct>   <chr>                  <dbl>              <dbl> #>  1         1 "the"      1       ""                    NA                 NA     #>  2         2 "girl"     2       "girl"                NA                 NA     #>  3         3 "walked"   3       "walk"                NA                 NA     #>  4         4 "down "    4       "down"                 0.261              1.28  #>  5         5 "the "     5       ""                    NA                 NA     #>  6         6 "street"   6       "street"               0.319              0.941 #>  7         7 "the"      7       ""                    NA                 NA     #>  8         8 "boxer"    8       "boxer"                0.938              0.858 #>  9         9 "punched"  9       "punch"                0.712              0.342 #> 10        10 "the"      10      ""                    NA                 NA     #> 11        11 "wrestler" 11      "wrestler"             0.720              0.294 #> 12        12 "open"     12      "open"                 0.791              0.706

title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
text: User specifies n-gram size (e.g., ngram=2). Distance computed two-word chunk next iterating way dataframe words ‘fill ’ last ngram.  Arguments dist_ngram2ngram :  | dat = dataframe w/ monologue sample cleaned prepped  | ngram = chunk size (chunk--chunk)

title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
text: example involves chunks 2-words 2-words
code: #Give the function a cleaned monologue transcript MyNgram2NgramDists <- dist_ngram2ngram(MyCleanMonologue2, ngram=2) head(MyNgram2NgramDists, n=8) #> # A tibble: 8 × 5 #>   id_orig word_clean CountID_Ngram2 CosDist_2gram_GLO CosDist_2gram_SD15 #>   <fct>   <chr>      <fct>                      <dbl>              <dbl> #> 1 1       ""         1                         NA                 NA     #> 2 2       "girl"     1                         NA                 NA     #> 3 3       "walk"     2                         NA                 NA     #> 4 4       "down"     2                          0.398              1.36  #> 5 5       ""         3                         NA                 NA     #> 6 6       "street"   3                          0.319              0.941 #> 7 7       ""         4                         NA                 NA     #> 8 8       "boxer"    4                          0.938              0.858

title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
text: Averages semantic vectors content words turn. Computes cosine distance average semantic vectors content words subsequent turn. Arguments ‘dist_dialogue_turns’ :  | dat = dataframe w/ dialogue sample cleaned prepped using ‘clean_dialogue’ fn

what: Output of ‘dist_dialogue_turns’ turn-to-turn distance on sample dialogue transcript

what: 2.4: Compute Distances Between Word Pairs in Columns (dist_2cols)
title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
text: data arrayed two columns interested computing pairwise distance across columns. critical argument dataframe name. Remember pass cleaned dataframe (even disable stopwords lemmatization). Arguments function:  | dat = cleaned dataframe two paired columns text Arguments ‘dist_2cols’ :  | dat = dataframe w/ word pairs arrayed columns cleaned prepped using ‘clean_2cols’ fn

previous_headings: 2.4: Compute Distances Between Word Pairs in Columns (dist_2cols)
title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
code: MyDistsColumns <- dist_2cols(MyClean2Columns) #only argument is dataframe head(MyDistsColumns, n=8) #>   word1     word2 id_orig word1_clean1 word2_clean2 CosDist_SD15 CosDist_GLO #> 1   Dog   trumpet       1          dog      trumpet    0.4534507   0.8409885 #> 2   the    BANANA       2          the       banana    1.1826228   0.7725166 #> 3   rat astronaut       3          rat    astronaut    1.2154729   0.9272540 #> 4  *&^%    lizard       4         <NA>       lizard           NA          NA #> 5  bird      bird       5         bird         bird    0.0000000   0.0000000 #> 6 shark     shark       6        shark        shark    0.0000000   0.0000000 #> 7 table     38947       7        table         <NA>           NA          NA #> 8   Dog     leash       8          dog        leash    0.6760924   0.5014043

what: 2.5: Compute Distance from a Fixed Cluster of Words in the Beginning of a Language Sample to each new word in the sample (anchor_dist)
title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
text: approach models semantic distance successive new word language sample average semantic vectors first block 10 content words sample. anchored distance provides metric overall semantic drift language sample unfolds relative fixed starting point. Arguments ‘anchor_dist’ :  | dat = dataframe w/ monologue sample cleaned prepped using ‘clean_monologue’ fn | anchor_size = size initial chunk words chunk--new-word comparisons fn

previous_headings: 2.5: Compute Distance from a Fixed Cluster of Words in the Beginning of a Language Sample to each new word in the sample (anchor_dist)
what: Output of ‘anchor_dist’ on a sample monologue transcript
title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
code: MyDistsAnchored <- dist_anchor(MyCleanMonologue2, anchor_size=8) head(MyDistsAnchored, n=10) #> # A tibble: 10 × 4 #>    id_orig word_clean CosDist_Anchor_GLO CosDist_Anchor_SD15 #>    <fct>   <chr>                   <dbl>               <dbl> #>  1 1       ""                     NA                  NA     #>  2 2       "girl"                  0.221               0.475 #>  3 3       "walk"                  0.186               0.649 #>  4 4       "down"                  0.141               0.625 #>  5 5       ""                     NA                  NA     #>  6 6       "street"                0.220               0.393 #>  7 7       ""                     NA                  NA     #>  8 8       "boxer"                 0.576               0.478 #>  9 9       "punch"                 0.603               0.348 #> 10 10      ""                     NA                  NA

previous_headings: 2.5: Compute Distance from a Fixed Cluster of Words in the Beginning of a Language Sample to each new word in the sample (anchor_dist)
what: 2.6: Compute Distance Matrix All Word Pairs (dist_matrix_all)
title: Computes Pairwise Cosine Distance Between Successive Units of Language Samples
text: Returns square matrix entry [,j] cosine distance word word j. Matrix contains original words row column names reference. User specifies whether return matrix based embeddings (GLOVE) experiential norms (SD15). Input unordered vector words cleaned/prepped ‘clean_unordered4matrix’ function Arguments ‘dist_matrix_all’ :  | dat = dataframe cleaned prepped using ‘clean_unordered4matrix’ fn | dist_type = quoted argument default ‘embedding’, option “SD15” fn
